root.pub-comments: Viegas Barros 2001: Colonial sources report the language was spoken by five “nations”: Tonocoté, Lule, Ysistiné, Toquistiné, and Oristiné (cf. Adelaar 2004:386). The sources, however, are difficult to interpret, leaving the true linguistic identity of Tonocoté unclear. Loukotka (1968:277) included in his “Lule stock”: Lule, Tonocoté, Isistiné, Oristine, Matará (Amualalá), and Jurí, saying nothing was known of any of these except Lule itself. Chunupí is commonly considered an alternative name for Vilela, though Loukotka (1968:53) considered it a distinct language in his Vilela stock. The designation of “Chunupí” in historical sources is unclear, and the name has also been assocated with Nivaclé (Chulupí, Ashlushlay; a Matacoan language), causing considerable confusion. Loukotka (1968:53) lists also as members of his Vilela stock the following extinct languages, of all of which he says nothing is known: Pasain, Ocole, Omoampa, Macomita, Yecamita, and Sinipi.
root.publications: Campbell, Lyle. The classification of South American languages. In Lyle Campbell & Verónica Grondona (eds.), South America. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. , Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 72. London, New York: Routledge.
